subject: Japan bought a net JPY 1.6tln in foreign bonds during March and foreign investors sold a net JPY 4.04tln in Japanese stocks during March, according to Ministry of Finance
Japanese Adjusted Current Account (JPY)(Feb) 1024B vs. Exp. 1390B (Prev. 2023B)
Japanese Trade Balance - BOP Basis (JPY)(Feb) 189B vs. Exp. 250B (Prev. -667B)
PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIAN, JAPANESE AND SOUTH KOREAN STOCK NEWS: Toshiba completes offloading Westinghouse stake, LG Electronics beats Q1 prelim. oper. profit estimates
content:
AUSTRALIA

Atlas Iron (AGO AT)
- Co. board is reportedly to recommend acquisition bid from Mineral Resources (MIN AT). (AFR)

Billabong (BBG AT)
- Australian Federal Court approves scheme of arrangement with Boardriders. (Newswires)

Bluescope Steel (BSL AT)
- Moody’s upgraded Co. credit rating to lowest level of investment grade at Baa3; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)

Elders (ELD AT)
- Co. is to acquire Titan Ag and Kerr & Co. Livestock, while it is to divest assets from Indonesian portfolio. (Newswires)

Fairfax Media (FXJ AT)
- Apollo executives are said to be in Sydney amid speculation of interest in the Co.’s regional papers. (AFR)

Macquarie Atlas (MQA AT)
- Co. reached agreement with Macquarie Group (MQG AT) regarding management internalization terms. (Newswires)

Magellan Financial Group (MFG AT)
- Co. March FUM AUD 65.3bln vs. Prev. AUD 65.4bln M/M. (Newswires)

Myer (MYR AT)
- Woolworths (WOW AT) reiterates it is not seeking to acquire the Co. (AFR)

National Australia Bank (NAB AT)
- Co. lays off 20 bankers from central credit risk operations as first step of its plan to cut workforce by 6000. (AFR)

Telstra (TLS AT)
- Australia’s small telecom firms are said to want Telstra to be trimmed down before the NBN is launched. (The Australian)

Ten Network (TEN AT) and Nine Entertainment (NEC AT)
- Co.s said to have launched new AUD 900mln bid for Cricket Australia media broadcasting rights. (The Australian)

Wesfarmers (WES AT)
- Several private equity firms are considering offers for Co. Homebase unit in UK. (Newswires)

Power Related
- Australian’s National Energy Guarantee could provide increased investment into fleet of mid-life coal-fired power plants, according to press reports. (AFR)

Basic Materials / Energy
- Spot gold rose 0.5%.
- WTI crude futures fell over 2% to briefly below USD 62/bbl.

 

JAPAN

Kyocera (6971 JT)
- Co. files lawsuit against Preh GmbH for possible infringement of Haptic Feedback Technology patent. (Newswires)

Lawson (2651 JT)
- Co. is to report first decline in profit in 15 years. (Nikkei)

SoftBank (9984 JT)
- Co. is reportedly mulling divestment of its Brightstar division. (Newswires)
- Co. was said to be raising funds for USD 8bln margin loan backed by stake in Alibaba (BABA).

Sumitomo Metal Industries (5405 JT)
- Co. President Nakazato has been named Chairman and Managing Executive Officer Nozaki has been named as next President effective June 2018. (Newswires)

Toshiba (6502 JT)
- Co.’s largest creditors are urging the Co. to move ahead with the sale of its memory chip unit for JPY 2tln, despite calculations by activist shareholder Argyle Street that it is worth over double that amount. (FT)
- Co. has completed offloading its stake in Westinghouse Electric, which could raise shareholder equity by as much as JPY 200bln. (Nikkei)

Other News
- China and Japan are preparing to resume high-level economic discussions this month for the 1st time in 8 years. (Newswires)

 

SOUTH KOREA

GS Engineering & Construction (006360 KS)
- Co. Q1 oper. profit rose 544% Y/Y to 380.4bln. (Yonhap)

Kakao (035720 KS)
- South Korea Transport Ministry states that Co. must abide by local regulations in regards to the introduction of a new option to its service which allows customers who pay an extra fee to get a taxi faster, which reports state would effectively place a cap on its fees. (Newswires)

LG Electronics (066570 KS)
- Co. Q1 prelim. Oper. profit rose 20% Y/Y to KRW 1.11tln vs. Exp. KRW 935bln, rev. KRW 15.1tln vs. Exp. KRW 15.4tln. (NDTV)

Samsung Electronics (005930 KS)
- Co. Vice Chairman Lee is expected to return to the management as head of AI. (Newswires)

Samsung Securities (106360 KS)
- Co. mistakenly paid out 1000 shares in dividends to employees instead of KRW 1000 due to a computational error. (Newswires)

SK Telecom (017670 KS)
- Co. is to compensate 7.3mln of its subscribers due to network issues on Friday.  (Newswires)

Lotte Group
- Lotte’s confectionery unit new president said that the unit wants to go public eventually. (Nikkei)

Shipbuilders
- Employee numbers in the shipbuilding industry declined for a 12th consecutive month with the number of worker in the industry down around 21% Y/Y. (Yonhap)

Geopolitical
- North Korea is reportedly prepared to discuss denuclearization, while reports added that Pyongyang has signalled progress towards denuclearization should move in phases in tandem with diplomatic and economic concessions from the US. (Newswires)
- China banned exports of items to North Korea that could potentially be used in WMDs to comply with UN resolution, while reports added that had identified 32 items which it will ban. (Newswires)

subject: US President Trump didn't seek advice from White House economic adviser Kudlow  on China tariffs, while Chief of Staff Kelly was said to be blindsided by speed of tariff announcements, according to Axios citing sources
content: - Furthermore, reports added that US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin and US Trade Representative Lighthizer worked in lockstep on the China tariffs.

subject: China bans exports of items to North Korea that could potentially be used in WMDs to comply with UN resolution
Norway private sector trade union reached wage deal which averted strike action that would have involved at least 35,000 workers in aluminium, oil and chemical industries
Twitter sources report that there is talk White House is close to a decision whether to hit Syria following the government's chemical weapons attack on its own people
Moody's says BoK will likely maintain key rate at upcoming meeting due to weak inflationary pressure
BoK says that South Korean lenders' offered real interest rates declined into negative territory last year
Apple (AAPL) is said to be likely to face sanctions from FTC in South Korea over dumping advertising and repair costs to local telecom operators
ASIAN DAILY ECONOMIC RELEASES CALENDAR NOW AVAILABLE IN THE RESEARCH SECTION: Highlights Include Australian AiG Performance of Construction Index and Japanese Current Account Balance
Reports note that no deal in principle regarding NAFTA is expected to be announced in the upcoming Summit of Americas in Lima, Peru
Hungary PM Orban is projected to win a 3rd term after ruling party is said to receive 49.5% of votes and is set to win two-thirds majority in Parliament
Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) names Christian Sewing to replace CEO John Cryan with immediate effect
ASIA-PAC SERVICE IS NOW LIVE FOR TODAY'S SESSION
DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

Chinese Foreign Exchange Reserves (USD)(Mar) 3.14T vs. Exp. 3.13T (Prev. 3.14T). (Newswires)

China's MOFCOM said on Friday it is ready and will not hesitate to retaliate, while it added that under these conditions the two parties cannot carry out any negotiations. MOFCOM also said that the economic ministers on both sides have not engaged in talks recently. (Newswires)
 

UK/EU

DBRS raised Spain's sovereign rating to A from A (low); stable trend. (Newswires)

S&P affirmed France at AA; Outlook stable. (Newswires)


FX

The USD was weaker with USD/JPY one of the notable movers on safe-haven flows into JPY amid swooning stocks and higher bonds. GBP also notably outperformed although the immediate reasoning was unclear with Bank of England Governor Carney avoiding monetary policy in his speech. Historically, April is a strong month for GBP and some analysts were pinning the move higher on seasonal factors. The CAD strengthened after relatively strong jobs data where job creation was higher than expected. However, lower oil prices, trade concerns and NAFTA uncertainty saw USD/CAD rebound to close relatively flat.

Canadian PM Trudeau said he is hopeful to get promising news on NAFTA in the coming time, while Canadian Foreign Minister Freeland said they have had good NAFTA conversations so far and that they are a in a new more intensive phase of discussions. Furthermore, there were also reports that a senior Mexican economy ministry official was said to be very convinced that a new NAFTA agreement on trade will be reached very soon and that the next round of NAFTA talks are planned for today in Washington DC. (Newswires)

Canadian Employment Change (Mar) 32.3k vs. Exp. 18.8k (Prev. 15.4k). (Newswires)
Canadian Unemployment Rate (Mar) 5.8% vs. Exp. 5.8% (Prev. 5.8%)


COMMODITIES

US Baker Hughes Total Rig Count (29 Mar) 1003 (Prev. 993). (Newswires)
 

GEOPOLITICAL

North Korea is reportedly prepared to discuss denuclearization, while reports added that Pyongyang has signalled progress towards denuclearization should move in phases in tandem with diplomatic and economic concessions from the US. (Newswires)

US President Trump warned Syrian President Bashar al-Assad and his 2 largest allies could pay a big price following a suspected chemical attack killed dozens over the weekend, while he also noted that Russia and Iran are responsible for backing the Syrian President. (Newswires)

Russia is to respond to US sanctions, according to reports in local press. (TASS)


US

Fed Chair Powell (Neutral) said the US economy will require further gradual interest rate hikes and noted 12-month inflation readings should move up notably this spring. Powell also commented that inflation could rise to unwelcome levels if the Fed waited for inflation and employment to hit its goals, while he added that it is too early to say how tariffs and trade talk will affect outlook. (Newswires)

Fed’s Williams (Voter, Hawk) said 3 to 4 hikes this year is the right direction and that Fed needs to keep raising rates to avoid overheating. (Newswires)

Fed’s Evans (Non-Voter, Dove) said that the US economy is very strong and that he is optimistic on inflation reaching 2% target. (Newswires)

White House Economic Advisor Kudlow said that he hopes the US will not use tariffs but added that it may have to, while he also stated that China’s first response is highly unsatisfactory. Furthermore, Kudlow also stated that a tariff solution is possible in 3 months and that tariffs are not a bluff. (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said the US is willing to continue negotiations but that President Trump is prepared to defend US interests. Mnuchin also commented that there is a potential for a trade war and that progress is being made on NAFTA as well as North Korea. (Newswires)

US Non-Farm Payrolls (Mar) 103k vs. Exp. 193k (Prev. 313k, Rev. 326k); 2-month net adjustment -50K. (Newswires)
US Unemployment Rate (Mar) 4.1% vs. Exp. 4.0% (Prev. 4.1%)
US Average Earnings YY (Mar) 2.7% vs. Exp. 2.7% (Prev. 2.6%)


MARKET RECAP

US equity markets declined on Friday after President Trump’s desire to increase Chinese tariff levels to USD 100bln. This led to futures dipping heavily in an immediate reaction on trade war concerns, which were paired slightly, but not enough to avoid a negative opening on Friday. This was maintained as the largest impetus for movement in equities throughout the day despite uninspiring employment data that missed expectations.

This miss on employment data, whilst seeing a small sell off in equities, was overawed by continued trade comments hammering stocks, with the Fed’s chair Powell saying trade wars are not a concern implying that rate increases will continue along the same path, putting further pressure on equities. This as well as comments from the White House seemingly shifting their focus from stock market prosperity to trade deficit reduction by accepting stock market volatility, saw equities close lower on the day.

The sectors you’d expect to underperform, underperformed. Materials (-2.4%) and industrials (-2.7%) sank as trade war concerns are expected to dampen global growth while financials (-2.4%) also struggled as rates declined amid the broad risk off tone. In stock specific news, all the companies in the Dow finished lower with just 12 companies in the S&P 500 higher on the day. SPX -2.2% at 2604.27, NDX -2.5% at 6433.21, DJI -2.3% at 23930.76.

US Treasuries closed higher as trade concerns and soft jobs data sent rates lower. Donald Trump’s threat to slap further tariffs on Chinese goods lifted treasuries before the CME open with the curve initially bull-steepening. The disappointing jobs data gave further impetus for bond bulls as the 10y yield dropped back below 2.8%. Fed Chairman Powell reiterated that further gradual rate hikes would be necessary, which saw market pricing for a June hike remain around 70%. However, odds of a fourth rate hike are still remarkably low as Powell said it was too early to say how tariffs and trade talk will affect the outlook. T-Note futures (June 2018) settled up 14+ ticks at 121-00+.
